annotation.TEXT: Even though I don't care much for his stage, I actually found Star Man to be a pretty fun fight in this game. Much like Skull Man, he's now completely invincible when he has his shield up. He doesn't tend to keep it up for long though, especially since he has some new variations on how he can fire it.

Hooray for more intentional deaths. The reason behind this one was to actually skip the mid-boss room (Magnet Man's stage is one of the few where you can actually bypass it). Punk happens to be weak to Magnet Man's weapon, and if I had gone back through this area, the only place I could proceed to would lead me directly to him. Trust me, it's well worth avoiding him whenever you can.

Also, don't worry too much if you accidentally destroy one of them. As a fail-safe of sorts, most of the Mag Flies instantly respawn if you kill them. There's a few of them that might not, but they're usually located in areas where you can just respawn them manually through screen transitions or by scrolling their spawn point back into view.

The the timing for the intended method here is pretty annoying, to be honest (and either way, I would have had to get a game over eventually to exit this stage). In any case, here's the Energy Saver. As its name implies, it basically doubles the ammo reserves of your weapons.

Alright, I've built up to him enough. Punk is annoying for one reason and one reason only: His new stomping attack. I hope you like being hit-stunned to death, because if he catches you with this move, you can pretty much say goodbye to a majority of your health.

The Mag Flies actually serve as a gimmick this time around. Once you're pulled up by them, you can freely control your vertical position (or at least, you can do so much faster than you could in the original MM3). Maneuvering like this is pretty much required to get through a good portion of this level.

Before we move on to the rest of the stages, there's something I want to get back in Magma Man's level that I previously mentioned. It's not entirely required to get this item, but it's definitely recommended, especially if you want an easier time managing your ammo reserves.

Magnet Missile is still pretty good, having solid damage output and speed to go with it. It still retains its 14 shot ammo count, though since I have the Energy Saver, this makes the act of reserving it for Punk much easier.

Star Crash has gotten a pretty significant buff. It deals out tremendous damage to nearly anything it hits, and it can keep going after blocking out several forms of projectiles. The drawback to this power boost is that its ammo has been insanely reduced. If you don't have the Energy Saver, you'll only be able to use this thing a total of 4 times before its ammo runs dry.

Thankfully, he didn't bother using the attack here. Moving on however, we now get a slight change to the mechanics in this stage. From this point on, low gravity is only active when you're over the space part of the background. The standard walls indicate areas where normal gravity is in effect. How all of this works, I have no idea.
